pullRequest.title: [ETE] Batching Txns, Attempt 2
pullRequest.bodyText:
Edit: I'm merging in #4750 and #4748 to this branch, so they need to be merged before we do final merge on this.
Goals (and why):
Start a batch of txns in one call.
Implementation Description (bullets):
Added a batch start transaction endpoint to the transaction manager. Guarantees to return either a full batch or throw an exception.
Testing (What was existing testing like?  What have you done to improve it?):
Have not implemented any tests yet
Concerns (what feedback would you like?):
Is this the right approach? Don't worry about details for now.
Where should we start reviewing?:
SnapshotTransactionManager, TransactionStarter
Priority (whenever / two weeks / yesterday):
whenever - this is a draft PR, so please only review decomp

commit.message: load more cleaning up I guess

nodes.bodyText: This class is copied from bottom of SnapshotTransactionManager - probably want to merge the two (if I can find a place where it makes sense to live in the project hierarchy).

+import java.util.function.Supplier;
+
+import com.palantir.logsafe.exceptions.SafeRuntimeException;
+
+public final class ExceptionHandlingRunner implements AutoCloseable {

nodes.bodyText: I need to spend a bit of time confirming what these do and determine the most efficient way to do this.

commit.message: Clean up method in corrobating timelock service
Add line to hit the batch part in profilling timelock service test
Add extra close call in case of empty responses

nodes.bodyText: We can probably optimise this in the batched case (only update once), if that is a performance concern.
What does "for the tasks" mean?
Refactor this check to a method.
Tests for this method, and I suppose for this whole class? The batching code is tricky, so definitely need tests for batching code.
Would it be a lot of overhead for removing the non-batched method here?
Again, would it make sense to only keep the batched method? count=1 should be simple to handle.
Running close should be enforced to only ever happen once. Also you should probably not allow adding more callbacks after close is called.
2 arguments of the same type, wink wink 😉
Generally it's nicer to allow fall through like this (so allow empty list), I think this is what the usage of this in internal ski product assumed.
This feels like a weird thing to check, the method you call should not return you a small response, that doesn't feel like a great API.
Shouldn't this method or something lower from here retry this instead? Feels like a bad thing to ask the users of this API to handle.
@jeremyk-91 to help verify; also probably need metrics to help answer this

Thoughts on returning something like TransactionAndImmutableTsLock, but that additionally has some sort of close method that users of this can call instead of using #finishRunTaskWithLockThrowOnConflict?
Should be @deprecated
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -433,6 +434,17 @@ default LockWatchManager getLockWatchManager() {
     @Timed
     TransactionAndImmutableTsLock setupRunTaskWithConditionThrowOnConflict(PreCommitCondition condition);
 
+    /**
+     * This method exposes the ability to start a batch of transactions with pre-commit conditions in a single call.
+     * The result is similar to calling {@link #setupRunTaskWithConditionThrowOnConflict(PreCommitCondition)}, except
+     * the code has been specifically optimised with respect to batching and error handling.
+     *
+     * @return a list of transactions and their associated immutable timestamp locks for the tasks
+     */
+    @Timed
+    List<TransactionAndImmutableTsLock> setupRunTaskBatchWithConditionThrowOnConflict(

nodes.bodyText: Please document that PreCommitConditions do not get cleaned up on errors.
We need to remove this method, since it is only supposed to be used by internal ski product.
Please check that this code you're moving is covered by extensive tests first, especially around resource cleanup on errors.
Again, how bad would it be to only have the batched method?
Batched method only.
Only batched method
Batched only.
Can someone explain why do we have this bizarre interface here with passing nulls?
Hmm, I guess we sometimes need to pass an actual argument here.

I think there's an argument for rewriting this to pass actual number of requested transactions to start? So that internal ski product's disruptors would actually become extremely tiny! Then the batch processor could just count number of transactions requested across the batch and send that to timelock?

we would save on a bunch of allocations for futures and lists for args here
We would get rid of the weird "null" passing of arguments?

@jeremyk-91 interested in your thoughts
Yeah, this is hopefully unnecessary.

So in this class we call #getStartTransactionResponses which is obviously already batched. But it's implementation can call timelock multiple times, without any cleanup of resources between calls: @jeremyk-91 does StartIdentifiedAtlasDbTransactionResponse not require any cleanup if we fail mid batch in this method?
Again, batched only.
Oh wait this is legacy; @jeremyk-91 this is mostly unused now right so don't need to worry about perf?
What's the cost of this #unlock call here, should it be batched?

Hard to say: this does a single atomic CAS so it shouldn't be too bad. Maybe just have a method wrapResponses that does the atomic update just once (with either the max of the immutable timestamps across the list, if we choose to be defensive, or the first element, if we want to rely on how creating batches normally goes)?

The timestamps are safe to drop on the floor, so the main thing we'd need to worry about here is the immutable timestamp lock, which you've handled.
I think @jkozlowski is asking about the impl of the existing getStartTransactionResponses method.
This is a good spot, and a bit of a spicy one: that method has a bug, though it is mostly benign. It does forget to unlock locks it may have taken on its way to completion, but as it is is unlikely to actively cause problems beyond delaying targeted sweep by 20 seconds. The failure mode is of course batch 1 succeeding but not having enough transactions, and batch 2 failing. In this case we still hold the locks, but they haven't been registered in the lock refresher yet so they go away after the lock timeout (20 seconds).
So this should be fixed, and it's probably an interesting one to do separately, but probably not a massive priority.
This isn't entirely safe implementation: if someone later decides to add something other than the response.ifPresent below here, you'll leak. You should somehow tie the below line to the supplySafely
Test, will fixup later.

This code is a bit messy, for sure - but more a proof of concept of how it would work.
Should definitely go in its own PR.
Again, this is now a single call, so there is no handling for what happens if there is a failure half-way through closing, as such a failure cannot occur.
Haven't looked at puncher in a while, so unclear if you can do this once for the whole batch same as immutable timestamp.
I quite like this, it's just an unwrapping and you're done. You could have a private method for setup*, but I'm not fussed either way.
You need to propagate the count?
You're relying on this not throwing. I think it's fine in this refactoring, but need to track fixing this, same as the other bug.

This is a bit sucky, since we're having to allocate Integers, while disruptor is optimised for that and reuses the actual instances of arguments, but I don't think it's worth obsessing about this. @jeremyk-91

@@ -45,38 +44,32 @@ * A service responsible for coalescing multiple start transaction calls into a single start transactions call. This * service also handles creating {@link LockTokenShare}'s to enable multiple transactions sharing a single immutable * timestamp. - * + *

* Callers of this class should use {@link #unlock(Set)} and {@link #refreshLockLeases(Set)} for returned lock tokens, * rather than directly calling delegate lock service. */ final class TransactionStarter implements AutoCloseable { - private final DisruptorAutobatcher autobatcher; + private final DisruptorAutobatcher> autobatcher;

nodes.bodyText: Probably want a test what happens when you push 0 here. Also should throw on negative.
Hmm, just think very carefully about what this subList does here. @jeremyk-91
Just want to check that this simple substitution still makes sense in the context above.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -123,7 +123,7 @@ public void close() {
      *
      * Retrying does theoretically mean that in the worst case with N transactions in our batch, we may actually
      * require N calls to the database, though this is extremely unlikely especially because of the semantics of
-     * {@link TimelockService#startIdentifiedAtlasDbTransaction()}.
+     * {@link TimelockService#startIdentifiedAtlasDbTransactionBatch(int)}.

commit.message: Yet another aggressive auto format on this particular paragraph
Get start timestamp instead of immutable timestamp
Fix small bug in unlocking in legacy timelock service

nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -418,24 +419,24 @@ default LockWatchManager getLockWatchManager() {
     void registerClosingCallback(Runnable closingCallback);
 
     /**
-     * This method can be used for direct control of a transaction's life cycle. For example, if the work done in
-     * the transaction is interactive and cannot be expressed as a {@link TransactionTask} ahead of time, this method
-     * allows for a long lived transaction object. For the any data read or written to the transaction to be valid,
-     * the transaction must be committed, preferably by calling
+     * This method can be used for direct control over the lifecycle of a batch of transactions. For example, if the
+     * work done in each given transaction is interactive and cannot be expressed as a {@link TransactionTask} ahead of
+     * time, this method allows for a long lived transaction object. For any data read or written to the transaction to
+     * be vvalid, the transaction must be committed, preferably by calling

nodes.bodyText: Are there any conditions on the ordering of transactions responses returned? Might be good to say what's allowed/not in case downstream users decide that looking at the first or last entry in the list to find some information

nodes.bodyText: Once per batch is fine, yep. Right now this is being called on every element right? I'd suggest we move it out and stick it next to the recordImmutableTimestamp
I guess this is fine - but depends on implementation, most of the time they are all going to be the same I think?
Yep, still correct.

      *
      * Retrying does theoretically mean that in the worst case with N transactions in our batch, we may actually

+     * {@link TimelockService#startIdentifiedAtlasDbTransactionBatch(int)}.

nodes.bodyText: Checked that no one uses this
fair enough. I think we have metrics for this? If we look at the delta between the rpc clients and setupRunTask... and that explodes that should give us a hint that this might be relevant.

nodes.bodyText: @Jolyon-S The tricky thing here is that subList keeps a reference to the original list, so the entire response will remain live in terms of memory as long as any consumer keeps a reference to their chunk of the list. This looks like it would probably be safe from tracing through the code, but I'd prefer to just create a new list in case there's something silly around threads contending over updateAndGet() or things like that.
❤️ Nice!
good reuse here :)

commit.message: Add unlock if failing mid-way through starting txns
Fix bug when fail to register lock

nodes.bodyText: Yeah, let's say that we can't assume that then

nodes.bodyText: Makes sense, let's just stick with this. We don't actually need the most up to date value for the tracker here (it's only for metrics), a good approximation is fine, but there isn't a regression here.
